5. Given the above circumstances, Mother should have been able to fully exercise her
visitation awarded to her in the Parties’ Final Order of Divorce. However, as seen by Father’s
prior history in blocking any and all visitation with the Minor Child A.K., it should come as
no surprise to this Court that Mother was unable to exercise her holiday visitation;
• The fact they stated “However, as seen by Father’s prior history in blocking any and
all visitation with the Minor Child A.K., it should come as no surprise to this Court
that Mother was unable to exercise her holiday visitation;” is a problem and a lie.
• Mother asserts that Father has a “history in blocking any and all visitation” with A.K.
and suggests this is why she was unable to exercise Christmas 2025 visitation. This
assertion is both unsupported by the record and mischaracterizes the procedural
history of this case.
o They have provided no proof that I have blocked any visation.
o The court agreed after an in camera interview with AK – Read Transcript. Use
Quote from Judge.
o Father did not deny visitation in willful disregard of the Court’s order. Rather,
as detailed in prior filings and incorporated herein, he informed Mother of a
long-planned church retreat for A.K. during the holiday window, which was
communicated on December 15, 2025, with the deposit having been paid
months earlier. – See attached Text messages
o The allegation that Father has a “history of blocking any and all visitation” is
contrary to the record. In fact, the Court has previously declined to find
Father in contempt. At the July 2024 hearing, Judge Perryman stated explicitly
that Father’s conduct did not amount to contempt, recognizing the child’s
unwillingness and the complexity of the situation.
o It is inaccurate to claim that Father “blocked” holiday visitation when, as
detailed in the prior response, A.K. herself declined to leave with her mother
on December 25, 2025. Father informed Mother in advance of A.K.’s church
retreat, attempted to facilitate the exchange, and encouraged A.K. to go. At
no point did he interfere with the order.
o This pattern does not reflect obstruction. It reflects ongoing adherence to the
Court’s directives under difficult circumstances involving a minor child with
unresolved emotional resistance to visitation—resistance that the Court has
acknowledged and structured its orders around.
o The Court has never found Father in contempt regarding visitation.
Assertions that he has ignored court warnings or acted willfully to prevent
Mother’s parenting time are not supported by rulings or the procedural
history. The record instead shows a consistent and cautious judicial
approach focused on gradual reunification and therapeutic readiness—not
forced visitation against a resistant child’s will.
o
6. On December 4, 2025, the undersigned’s office reached out to opposing counsel to
confirm the holiday visitation dates per the agreement. Opposing counsel stated, “Blaine’s
Christmas is from 12-18-2025 to Christmas Day (12-25) at 6:00, then Brittany has 12-25 at
6:00 until 1-1-2026 at 6:00 for her Christmas, then her weekend would be Jan 2, 3, 4,” which
the undersigned then confirmed and relayed to Mother. The undersigned corrected that the
pick-up time for Mother on December 25, 2025 is in fact 12:00pm, not 6:00pm which
opposing counsel previously stated, which was confirmed by the opposing counsel in order
to avoid any potential miscommunication between Mother and Father when the time to
exchange the Minor Children came;
• Further undermining Mother’s argument, she failed to exercise her regular
custodial weekend immediately following the holiday. On January 1, 2026, she
returned Bennett to Father at approximately 6:00 p.m. but did not return to pick him
up for her scheduled visitation from January 2 through January 4. This occurred
despite her claim that she coordinated exchange plans through counsel to avoid any
confusion. No contact or attempt was made by Mother to retrieve Bennett for that
visitation period. This omission reflects a lack of follow-through on Mother’s part
and contradicts the narrative that miscommunications or Father’s actions have
obstructed her access to the children.
7. On December 21, 2025, the Parties met for their weekly family dinner. During this dinner,
Father explained that the Minor Child, A.K., had planned for an extracurricular trip through
her church from December 27, 2025 until January 6, 2026. This would “coincidentally”
conflict with Mother’s holiday visitation which was to begin on December 25, 2025 and end
on January 1, 2026. Since this was during Mother’s visitation, she had arranged for A.K. to
attend a family gathering before promptly returning A.K. to Father’s home for her trip;
• Response to Allegation No. 7 – Alleged Withholding of Information and
Mischaracterization of Trip
• Mother claims that Father interfered with visitation and failed to provide information
related to A.K.’s holiday plans, referring specifically to an “extracurricular trip.” This
allegation is inaccurate and omits essential facts.
• The trip at issue was not a generic extracurricular activity—it was a church youth
retreat organized by First Baptist Church in Alexander City, Alabama, scheduled for
December 27 through December 30, 2025, in Gatlinburg, Tennessee. Father
informed Mother of the trip well in advance and sought her input and permission.
On December 15, 2025, Father texted Mother stating:
• “AK wants to do this… it’s $200. It’s 12/27 – 12/30. Do you have a problem with her
going out of state to TN for it?”
• He also attached the official link to the church’s Winterblast 2025 page, providing
full details of the event and payment information. At no point did Mother respond
with any objection or concern. Then, on December 26, 2025, Father sent another
message to remind Brittany of the trip and offer her a chance to speak with A.K.
before departure:
• “AK leaves for TN in the morning for winterblast. I have to have her at the church at
7am – they return Tuesday. Call her tonight before she leaves.”
• These texts, backed by screenshots, show clear communication, transparency, and
an opportunity for Mother to participate. The claim that the trip was concealed is
contradicted by this documented effort to inform and involve her.
• Point out it’s a lie that I told Brittany about this trip duing the 12/21 Dinner as proof
provided by the text. Point out that the trip was not from 12/27 until 1/6 but just as I
outlined in the text it was from 12/27 – 12/30.
8. Following this dinner, Mother received a phone call from Father where he had only
mentioned the Minor Child, B.M., for holiday visitation;
• Mother asserts that Father’s use of only one child’s name during a phone call
was intended to exclude or imply that A.K. would not be made available for
visitation. This assumption is incorrect and unsupported.
• If Father referenced only one child (such as Bennett) during a call, it was not
intended to imply that A.K. would be withheld. The name mentioned likely
reflected the specific logistical detail being discussed at that moment—not an
exclusion of the other child. At no time did Father state or suggest that A.K.
would not be made available. In fact, A.K. was present and available for the
December 25, 2025 exchange, and Brittany personally interacted with both
children during that time.
• The last contact between the parties prior to the holiday exchange occurred
before Father left the December 21, 2025 family dinner in Prattville, Alabama.
That gathering—attended by Brittany, her husband, their children, and Brittany’s
extended family—did not conclude until approximately 10:30 p.m. Father then
made the 1.5-hour drive back to Alexander City and did not have further
communication with Brittany before the scheduled exchange. The fact that
Brittany saw both children on December 25, spoke with A.K., and invited her to
join a family event confirms that A.K. was not being hidden or withheld.
• Father complied with the Court’s holiday order, and any mention of only one
child during a phone call cannot be reasonably interpreted as an attempt to
interfere with or mislead regarding visitation.
10. When the exchange of the Minor Children occurred on December 25, 2025,
Father asked if the pick-up time could be pushed back one hour so that Minor Child
B.M. could play with his Christmas present. Mother informed Father that she was
already on the road to pick up the Minor Children, to which Father then informed
B.M. that Mother refused to allow him to play with his toy, causing B.M. to be upset
with Mother upon Mother’s arrival. This was another manipulation tactic by Father
to foster negative emotions towards Mother and to change the Minor Child’s
perception of Mother;
• Mother alleges that Father made disparaging remarks to the parties’ minor
son, B.M., on Christmas Day, specifically claiming that Father told B.M. that
“his Mother refused to allow him to play with his toys,” causing B.M. to be
upset with her upon her arrival. This allegation is entirely false and
misrepresents the events of that day.
• On December 25, 2025, Father called Mother at 11:00 a.m., one hour before
the scheduled 12:00 p.m. pickup time, to ask when she would arrive. Brittany
confirmed that she was already on her way. Father did not inform Bennett
that his mother was coming to pick him up until she had already arrived,
specifically to avoid upsetting him in advance. When Father told Bennett
that his mother was outside, Bennett became visibly upset about the
transition.
• To help ease the exchange and make the moment more positive, Father
asked Brittany’s husband, Bradley, to take a picture of him with the children
on the front steps. He also invited Brittany to take a picture with them, and
she agreed. Because Bennett was still emotional, Father suggested that
everyone do “pouting faces” in the photos to help lighten the mood and
make it feel more playful. A copy of that photo is attached as evidence.
• In further effort to support the transition, Father asked Bennett if he wanted
to show his mom what Santa had brought. When Bennett said yes, Father
invited Brittany and her husband into the home, and Bennett proudly
showed them his new gaming PC in the playroom. During this brief visit,
Father also introduced Bradley to his father. Afterward, everyone went back
outside, and Father placed Bennett in Brittany’s vehicle.
• The suggestion that Father told Bennett something negative about his mother
is unsupported and contradicted by these actions. Father clearly made every
effort to create a warm, peaceful, and emotionally supportive exchange—not
one based in tension or manipulation.
• Father has consistently gone above and beyond to support the children's
relationship with their mother, including:
• Moving Christmas (Santa) to December 23 to prevent B.M. from
experiencing the emotional conflict of receiving gifts and then having to leave
a few hours later on Christmas Day;
• Facilitating calls between the children and Brittany the night before and
the morning of Santa’s visit at his home;
• Bringing both children to attend Brittany’s church’s candlelight service in
Clanton on December 21st then making another 1 hr drive and to have
Christmas dinner with Brittany’s extended family in Prattville on
December 21 and then driving 1.20 min home that night.
• Participating in a family dinner and Walmart outing just days before this
filing, during which Brittany took pictures of Father with her infant daughter.
• These events show a consistent pattern of cooperation and care—not
alienation or manipulation. Father categorically denies making any
statement to B.M. that would cast Mother in a negative light, and he strongly
objects to the repeated use of language suggesting that he employs
“manipulation tactics.” The documented facts show otherwise: that Father
supports co-parenting and has acted in the best interests of both children.
11. Furthermore, Father’s sister, Katie McGregor, was at Father’s residence helping the
Minor Child ,A.K., pack for her trip at the time of the visitation exchange. When Mother
asked if A.K. was coming with B.M. into the car for pick up, Father reportedly stated “if you
want to go you can go” to A.K., to which she declined and went back inside Father’s
residence;
• Mother alleges that Addie Kate was “packing for her church youth trip” during the
scheduled Christmas Day pickup, implying she was unavailable. This is false. At the
time of the exchange on December 25, 2025, at 12:00 p.m., A.K. was not packing.
Both children came outside for the exchange. Photos were taken of the family on the
front steps. Afterward, everyone returned inside briefly so Bennett could show
Brittany and Bradley his Christmas gifts. Father then placed Bennett in Brittany’s
vehicle.
• While outside, Brittany asked A.K. if she would like to go with her to a family
gathering at Bradley’s family’s home. She told A.K. she would bring her back later
that evening. Father encouraged A.K. to go, but did not pressure her. As the
discussion continued between A.K. and her mother, Father stated:
• “This is between you and your mother,”
and then went inside the home. About ten minutes later, A.K. came inside. Father
did not interfere in their discussion and did not obstruct the visitation.
• Mother’s additional claim that “Katie” was present in the home during this exchange
is also false. Katie is not Father’s sister, but his sister-in-law, and she was not
present at the home during the pickup. Dated and timestamped video
surveillance footage from Katie’s residence confirms that she remained at her own
home until approximately 3:00 p.m. on Christmas Day—three hours after the
exchange occurred. The only other person present at Father’s home during the
pickup was his father.
• This is another unsupported accusation and a clear attempt to misrepresent the
facts before the Court.
12. This Court has been explicitly clear regarding visitation especially as it relates to putting
the responsibility of exercising visitation in the Minor Child A.K.’s hands. Father has
previously made and continues to make zero attempt to encourage visitation between the
Minor Child A.K. and Mother and consistently engages in parental alienation;
• Father did not unilaterally “leave the decision up to the child.” If Mother had wished
to enforce the visitation or believed Father was obstructing it, she could have
involved law enforcement, as she has on prior occasions. She did not do so. The
Court has never found Father in contempt for these exchanges, and in fact, both
counsel and the Court agreed after the in camera interview with A.K. that the
previously scheduled show cause hearing would not proceed. That decision
followed the Court’s acknowledgment that A.K.’s statements carried weight in
determining visitation progress.
• Accusations that Father has made “zero attempts” to support visitation or that he
engages in “parental alienation” are direct attacks on his character and are not
supported by the record. Father has encouraged visitation, attended therapy,
facilitated communication, and followed the court’s orders. The in camera interview
and court’s subsequent actions contradict Mother’s narrative.
13. On July 24, 2025, this Court issued an Order stating, in part, “Both parties are to parent
and not permit the/a child to control the operations of this Court’s orders.” See July 24,
2025 Order [Doc. 222]
• Mother previously attempted to enforce visitation under an outdated version of the
custody order, despite the fact that a newer Temporary Order was in effect. Her
filing to enforce a superseded schedule prompted Father to file a Motion to Clarify,
which was granted by the Court on August 7, 2025. That order confirmed the most
recent order controlled and clarified that the schedule Mother was attempting to
enforce was no longer valid. Both the April 14, 2025 Temporary Order and the
August 7, 2025 Clarification Order are attached.
• These events show that any confusion in the record stemmed from Mother’s
attempt to act under a repealed order—not from Father’s conduct.
14. This Court also stated during the July 31, 2024 Show Cause Hearing that “I don’t mind
talking to her again and letting her know if she don’t do what I tell her she’s got to do, then I
may have to change custody.” See Transcript page 6, lines 16-18 [Doc. 138] and, “A ten-
year-old can’t tell us what we’re going to do,” See Transcript page 6, line 25 [Doc. 138];
• Mother cites early remarks made by Judge Perryman, such as:
• “I don't mind talking to her again and letting her know if she don't do what I tell her
she's got to do, then I may have to change custody, and a ten-year-old can't tell us
what we're going to do.”
• These comments were made before the judge heard any evidence and before
conducting the in camera interview with A.K. After speaking with A.K. directly,
Judge Perryman shifted tone significantly. He ordered only weekly family dinners
as visitation and denied reunification therapy, responding to Mother’s counsel’s
question with:
• “No, not now.”
• He made clear that the Court would not force visitation without therapeutic support
and emotional readiness. The in camera interview was central to this shift in the
Court’s approach, demonstrating the judge’s responsiveness to the facts and to
A.K.’s lived experience.
15. This Court’s position has been made clear since the initiation of this action that the
Minor Child is not to dictate whether visitation is to be exercised. Father has continued to
blatantly disregard this Court’s orders and refuses to bear any responsibility for ensuring
that visitation is properly exercised. Father continues to place this burden onto a minor and
instills distaste towards A.K.’s own mother, creating a rift and severing any familial bond
that Mother attempts to create, which is the definition of parental alienation. Indeed,
Father has even successfully blocked the reunification therapy that was ordered by the
Court with no consequences;
• Christopher Blaine McGregor (“Father”) has scrupulously followed the court’s
custody and visitation orders and, in many instances, exceeded their requirements
to facilitate the children’s relationship with Brittany Gilliland (“Mother”). As Father
affirms, “I have fully complied with all court-ordered visitation arrangements and
often exceeded them to support the children’s relationship with their Mother.” Far
from instilling distaste for Mother or alienating the children, Father has consistently
encouraged contact and goodwill. For example, during holidays in 2024 – when the
Final Decree did not entitle Mother to Thanksgiving custody – Father voluntarily
arranged extra time for Mother to be with the children. He allowed Mother to have
dinner with A.K. on Thanksgiving Eve and spend special time with the younger child,
even though this was beyond what the court order required. On Mother’s Day 2025,
Father helped both children prepare gifts for Mother and invited Mother to join A.K.
for dinner – an offer Mother declined. Father still brought A.K. out to Mother’s car
that day to ensure A.K. could hand over the gifts and personally wish Mother a
happy Mother’s Day. These actions demonstrate Father’s good-faith efforts to
nurture, not undermine, the mother–child bond.
• At no point has Father engaged in a campaign of disparagement or blocked the
children’s communication with Mother. In fact, the record shows Father facilitated
phone calls, gift exchanges, and counseling sessions aimed at reunifying Mother
and A.K.. He has never spoken negatively about Mother to the children.
• Father has obeyed both the letter and spirit of those provisions. The only
impediments to Mother’s relationship with A.K. have been those arising from A.K.’s
own well-founded emotional reservations and Mother’s repeated failure to take
advantage of visitation opportunities – not any interference or poisoning of the well
by Father.
• Father Did Not “Let the Child Control” Visitation: Allegation 15 claims Father
allows the minor child to dictate visitation. This is incorrect. Father has encouraged
A.K. to attend scheduled visits and therapy, but he also must respond to the reality
of A.K.’s trauma and fear.
• What Father refuses to do is forcibly drag a terrified child into a car against her
will without addressing the underlying issues. As he explained, “I cannot in good
conscience force our child into a situation that she finds scary or traumatic.” This
approach is entirely consistent with the Court’s guidance. At the July 31, 2024
hearing (before A.K.’s in-camera interview), Judge Perryman emphasized that the
goal was to avoid “screwing up” the child and to rebuild trust gradually: “we’re going
to send everybody to counseling, and then we’ll be back here and see if we can’t get
things better.” The Judge made clear that reunification therapy should start slowly –
first with A.K. and her individual counselor, then joint sessions with Mother “after
y’all have some indication … that things are progressing”. In line with that intent,
Father has prioritized A.K.’s emotional well-being while encouraging her to heal and
eventually resume normal visitation. He is not “controlled” by the child; he is
following professional and court guidance to ensure that contact is meaningful and
not harmful.
Mother Missed ~50% of Court-Ordered Reunification Dinners: The contempt allegation
faults Father for allegedly withholding visitation, but the factual record shows it has been
Mother who failed to show up to visitation opportunities. After the divorce, the Court
ordered weekly “reunification dinners” to help reintroduce Mother into A.K.’s life (originally
Wednesday evenings, later moved to Sundays). From January through August 2025, roughly
30 weekly reunification dinners were scheduled – and Mother missed more than half of
them. Some she canceled in advance with flimsy excuses; others she simply no-showed,
leaving A.K. waiting. Each absence is documented in text messages and logs (Exhibits A–C)
– for example, on January 10, 2025, Mother asked to reschedule a dinner to Saturday
morning, which Father agreed to, but then Mother never appeared at the rescheduled
time. On February 12, 2025, Mother neither showed up nor gave notice, then later tried to
blame Father by claiming she wasn’t informed of the plan (despite a standing court order
and shared Google calendar). The pattern continued through the spring and summer:
Easter Sunday (April 20, 2025) – Mother failed to participate; Mother’s Day (May 11, 2025) –
Mother again skipped the chance to see A.K., aside from picking up the younger child;
multiple Sundays in June–August 2025 – Mother would cancel last-minute or simply never
respond to Father’s messages about meeting times. By August, Mother was outright
refusing to come to the designated location (Alexander City) at all, insisting Father drive
A.K. to meet her halfway – contrary to the court’s order that Mother exercise visitation in
Alex City. In sum, Mother’s own choices “resulted in any disruption of visitation,” not
Father’s actions. Father, for his part, kept every weekly dinner slot open, had the children
ready and waiting, and frequently reached out to confirm Mother’s plans – only to be met
with silence or cancellations. He even adjusted schedules repeatedly at Mother’s request
(e.g. moving visits from Wednesdays to Sundays to accommodate Mother’s work and
relocation). The undisputed record is that Father was present for every scheduled
exchange; it was Mother who more often failed to appear or cut visits short.
Mother Missed ~75% of A.K.’s Medical Appointments: The allegation that Father blocks
Mother from the child’s life is further disproven by Mother’s own absence at critical events
like doctor’s appointments. Father has kept Mother informed of all major medical visits for
the children. Yet Mother has attended only a small fraction of A.K.’s medical and therapy
appointments since the divorce. The attendance log of health visits (Exhibit __) shows that
Mother was a no-show for roughly three out of every four appointments. By way of
illustration, at A.K.’s pediatric sick visit on August 28, 2023, the clinic records note
“Brittany – No Show”, with Father having to accompany A.K. alone. This was not an
isolated incident – it is representative of a trend. Mother consistently failed to appear
despite having joint notice and rights, thereby forgoing opportunities to engage in A.K.’s
health and daily life. It is ironic for Mother to accuse Father of blocking communication with
the school or medical providers, when the reality is Mother seldom shows up even when
she is expected. Father cannot be blamed for Mother’s own lack of involvement. To the
contrary, Father has never barred Mother from any school or medical information – he has
provided updates and even added Mother to shared calendars for events. If Mother missed
a vaccine appointment or a school function, it was due to her absence or inattention, not
because Father hid it from her. In fact, the Final Decree’s joint legal custody terms require
both parents to confer on major decisions, and Father has abided by that – for instance,
consulting Mother about A.K.’s counseling and inviting her input on activities. It is Mother
who chose not to attend or sometimes not even to respond.
Mother Missed ~94% of A.K.’s Extracurricular Activities: Father also documents that
Mother has rarely supported A.K. at her extracurricular activities. A.K. is an active pre-teen
with sports and school events. Father ensured Mother was informed of all games, recitals,
and activities, and the schedule was readily available. Yet Mother’s attendance has been
abysmal. Out of A.K.’s entire 2024–2025 sports season, Mother attended only 1 of 12 of
A.K.’s soccer games, 2 of 16 of her cheer/football games, and 0 of 30 basketball games. In
total, Mother was present for just 3 out of 58 games – a 5% attendance rate, meaning she
missed approximately 94% of A.K.’s events. Again, this underscores that if anyone has been
absent from the child’s life, it is Mother. Father, by contrast, was at every game or practice,
and even took on all the driving and expenses for these activities (often with no
contribution from Mother). Father also made sure Mother knew she was welcome at all
events; he never discouraged her from coming. Her near-total non-attendance speaks for
itself. It is simply not credible for Mother to claim Father “alienated” the child, when Mother
has voluntarily alienated herself by failing to show basic support and presence. As Father
notes, he has “gone out of my way to facilitate Mother’s visitation, and it is Mother who has
often been unable or unwilling to utilize the time allotted to her.” Any suggestion that Father
prevented Mother from being involved is flatly false.
In summary, the evidence of the past two years shows Father has bent over backwards to
include Mother – flexible scheduling, extra holiday time, constant communication – while
Mother has spurned half or more of the opportunities given to her. This directly refutes
Allegation 15’s premise that Father is the one flouting court orders or poisoning the
children’s minds. On the contrary, Father’s compliance and facilitation are well-
documented, and it is Mother’s pattern of non-compliance that has hindered her
relationship with A.K.
Father’s Efforts to Encourage and Continue Reunification Therapy
Allegation 15 also accuses Father of “blocking reunification therapy.” The record proves the
opposite. Father has been the driving force behind initiating, maintaining, and when
necessary, re-starting reunification therapy between Mother and A.K. Far from impeding
therapy, Father has diligently followed every court directive and even sought corrections
when the process derailed due to no fault of his own.
Court’s Intent vs. Written Order: It is important to recall the court’s intended plan for
reunification therapy. During the July 31, 2024 hearing (where the Court interviewed A.K. in
camera), Judge Perryman made the gradual approach clear on the record: A.K. would first
continue individual counseling (with Mother participating in some of those sessions), and
only after progress was observed would a separate reunification therapist commence joint
Mother–daughter therapy. The Judge specifically said Mother should attend counseling
sessions with A.K.’s regular counselor “at least eight/ten times” and “that needs to start
immediately”, and “then a separate reunification [counselor] after we get down the road
with this a little bit and see if we can’t get things better.”*. Father understood this phased
plan and agreed with it – it aligned with ensuring A.K. was emotionally ready. However,
when the written order came out on November 6, 2024, it omitted the phase-in sequence
and instead directed that reunification therapy with a specific counselor (Kelly Turner)
begin right away. Despite concerns that this contradicted the court’s stated intent, Father
complied fully with the November 6 order. He did not challenge or ignore it; rather, he
promptly facilitated the ordered therapy: he allowed Mother’s attorney to choose the
reunification therapist (Ms. Turner), let Mother set the initial appointments, and made
A.K. available for every scheduled session.
Full Compliance and Participation: Father never impeded the reunification counseling. To
the contrary, he went to great lengths to make it successful. He provided a shared Google
calendar to both Mother and Ms. Turner to coordinate sessions and communicated his
openness and availability for any appointment. Father made sure to attend with A.K. every
session that was scheduled and communicated to him. He even rearranged other family
plans – for example, cutting short a family Christmas gathering on December 23, 2024 –
because Mother and Ms. Turner set a therapy session that day. (Notably, Mother herself
missed that December 23 session after insisting on it; she and the therapist canceled last-
minute after Father and A.K. had already altered their holiday plans to attend.) Father’s
dedication is summed up in his affidavit: “I attended with A.K. whenever sessions were set,
and I went so far as to leave holiday family time and rearrange schedules to make therapy a
priority.” He never once refused a session, never showed up late (aside from instances
where Mother failed to confirm times), and never caused a cancellation. In fact, Father
confirms, “I never missed or canceled a session that I was made aware of, and I
accommodated every appointment that was communicated to me.” The same cannot be
said for Mother – it was her inconsistent scheduling and attendance that undermined the
continuity of therapy.
• Therapist Kelly Turner’s Withdrawal: The reunification therapy with Ms. Turner
ultimately fell apart not because of any act of Father, but because Ms. Turner herself
unilaterally withdrew from the case after only two joint sessions. Critically, Ms.
Turner’s own communications and affidavit make clear why she quit – and it was not
due to Father “blocking” anything. On February 12, 2025, Ms. Turner submitted an
affidavit (since she could not attend a hearing) in which she made certain
“prejudicial statements regarding the Father” despite never having met or spoken
with him in person. She admitted her conclusions were based solely on limited
email interactions. Father’s counsel rightfully sought to cross-examine these
conclusions by noticing Ms. Turner for a deposition on February 14, 2025. That
same night (Feb. 14), at 11:46 PM, Ms. Turner emailed both parties stating: “I am
removing myself from this case. I wish you both the best… I am not going to be able
to continue to assist moving forward. If you need any suggestions for other
therapists I can provide options.” Ms. Turner specifically referenced an email from
Father (in which Mother was allegedly not copied) as the reason for her abrupt
withdrawal. Father was baffled by this, as he had included Mother on all
communications and immediately responded asking what email she was referring
to. It later emerged that Mother had been emailing Ms. Turner separately behind the
scenes – for example, Mother confirmed an appointment time with Ms. Turner via a
private email that excluded Father. Thus, any confusion about who was attending
or confirming sessions was caused by Mother’s unilateral communications, not by
Father. Ms. Turner apparently “felt” manipulated by the situation (perhaps due to
these crossed communications) and chose to quit. But the key point is this: Father
did not fire or pressure the therapist to withdraw. Ms. Turner’s own affidavit
states, “this situation felt highly manipulative and… I realized that this process was
not going to be conducive nor effective, and a decision was made to withdraw.”
Those were her words and decision. Father was blindsided by Ms. Turner’s exit; he
had been preparing to attend every session and was “ready and willing to continue
the reunification therapy” with her. There is no evidence whatsoever that Father
caused or encouraged Ms. Turner’s withdrawal. In fact, the evidence shows the
opposite – Father was dismayed by her quitting and took immediate steps to get the
therapy back on track with a new
• Allegation 15 also accuses Father of “blocking reunification therapy.” The record
proves the opposite. Father has been the driving force behind initiating,
maintaining, and when necessary, re-starting reunification therapy between Mother
and A.K. Far from impeding therapy, Father has diligently followed every court
directive and even sought corrections when the process derailed due to no fault of
his own.
• Court’s Intent vs. Written Order: It is important to recall the court’s intended plan
